column1:
. '
                Last increment ID is: %s. Please change pattern. Supposed Increment ID: %s'
column2:
. '
                Last increment ID is: %s. Please change pattern. Supposed Increment ID: %s'

column1: You can use variables {counter}, {store}, {yyyy}, {yy}, {m}, {mm}, {d}, {dd}, {rand}, {order_id}, {country_code}. If you type ORD-{yy}-{mm}-{dd}-{counter} in the field, you will have order numbers of the kind: ORD-13-08-15-000077
column2: You can use variables {counter}, {store}, {yyyy}, {yy}, {m}, {mm}, {d}, {dd}, {rand}, {order_id}, {country_code}. If you type ORD-{yy}-{mm}-{dd}-{counter} in the field, you will have order numbers of the kind: ORD-13-08-15-000077

column1: E.g. the last number is 00015. If increment step is 4, the next number will be 00019
column2: E.g. the last number is 00015. If increment step is 4, the next number will be 00019

column1: Total number of digits in the order number. If the order id is 24 and padding is 6, the result will be 000024. Set to 0 (zero) not to add leading zeros.
column2: Total number of digits in the order number. If the order id is 24 and padding is 6, the result will be 000024. Set to 0 (zero) not to add leading zeros.

column1: Will be added before the order number
column2: Will be added before the order number

column1: Part of the order number to replace with the prefix
column2: Part of the order number to replace with the prefix

column1: If you have the order number as `11/13-order`, you can replace the `-order` part with the prefix instead of adding it in the beginning.
column2: If you have the order number as `11/13-order`, you can replace the `-order` part with the prefix instead of adding it in the beginning.

column1: You can use variables {counter}, {store}, {yyyy}, {yy}, {m}, {mm}, {d}, {dd}, {rand}, {order_id}, {country_code}. If you type INV-{yy}-{mm}-{dd}-{counter} in the field, you will have invoice numbers of the kind: INV-13-08-15-000077
